newsitem.title: USA: Ohio Senate approves school funding reform plan.
newsitem.headline: Ohio Senate approves school funding reform plan.

text.p: The Ohio Senate on Tuesday approved a $1.1 billion sales tax increase as part of a package of bills authorizing an overhaul of the system for funding the state's public schools, a Senate aide said.

The proposed changes, which require the voter approval, also require school districts to create "rainy day" funds, forecast future spending needs and meet academic standards, John Rabenold, an aide to Senate President Richard Finan, said.

"Does this solve all the problems? No, but it is a good start," said Sen. Merle Kearns, Republican of Springfield. Kearns is chairwoman of the Senate Education Committee, which reviewed the academic and fiscal accountability issues.

The majority Republican Senate voted 21-11 along party lines to approve the financing plan, which includes a 20 percent rollback on property taxes. The package excludes an increase in the cigarette tax recommended by Gov. George Voinovich's school funding taskforce.
The Ohio Supreme Court in March overturned the state's school funding formula and gave lawmakers one year to create a system less dependant on local property taxes.
The Voinovich taskforce recommended increasing state aid by $1.1 billion in the current biennium and providing $5.8 billion for capital improvements over the next 10 years.
Brian Rothenberg, a spokesman for Ohio Senate Democrats, said the plan would not raise enough money to satisfy the state Supreme Court or meet the taskforce's recommendations.
The Senate plan would raise the state sales tax from 5 percent to 6 percent to generate about $1.1 billion annually and increase taxes on businesses and commercial properties.

The legislation now goes to the Ohio House. Republicans hold a 60-to-39 majority in the House, but are expected to need some assistance from Democrats to reach the 60 percent margin necessary to pass the bill, Rothenberg said.
Lawmakers must approve constitutional amendments by August 6 if the referendum questions are to be placed on the November ballot.
